SVMs are a type of learning machines applied to a wide range of applications
machine learning, optimization, statistics, neural networks, functional analysis to pattern recognition problems
But for now I will present only the use of SVM for text classification problems
In this method training and test examples are represented as d-dimensional real vectors
in the space of features describing the data.
Given a category, each example belongs to one of two classes referred to as positive and negative
so it is only a two class classifier?
one example can belong to more classes
but for one class an example can be in it (reffered as possitive) or can not (reffered as negative)

so ana before the break you were talking about the SVM classes
yes claudiu
i will continue..in mathematical way we can say the training set consists of pairs (xi, yi), i = 1..n
where xi is a d-dimensional vector and represents the i-th training vector
and yi is +1 or -1 and represents the class label of this instance.
The SVM algorithm treats learning as an optimization problem
that is identical to the way data is represented in the k-means algorithm
yes, they are very similar in that matter
yes iti is true
the different part is in the separation algorithm
The learner attempts to separate positive from negative instances
using a hyperplane of the form wT x = b where w and b are variables defining the hiperplane
To choose w and b, SVM minimizes the a given criterion function.
Once w and b are calculated, the classifier uses a criterion to predict class labels of new documents
what about training SVM?
SVM has two phases
In the training stage, the correspondence between every input vector and given output is internally discovered and learnt
The input for my model are the d-dimensional vectors and the label
discovered?
insn't it told what the correspondence is? a priori i mean?
so in the training stage the method calculates w and b
yes claudiu..the label tels the algorith the correspondence
i understand, but you said that it evolves, that it is an optimisation problem
The algoritm takes a lot of d-dimensional vectors and their labels for each document
how is that?
and finds b and w described above claudium_ro: how is that
yes
i will explain
The optimisation problem is represented by the minimization of a given criterion function.
The space between the planes wT x = b ± 1 is called the margin
its width can be expressed as a function of w: 2/||w||
The criterion function that is minimized by SVM causes the learner
to look for a trade-off between minimizing the term ||w||2
which is equivalent to maximizing the width of the margin, on one hand, and minimizing the classification errors over the training data
This is the trainig stage
Afterwords the classifier uses the following criterion to predict class labels of new documents
prediction(x) := sgn(wT x - b)
This is basicly the SVM method

that works well when very few training examples is available to the learner

The ART (Adaptive Resonance Theory) neural networks are known for their self-organizing pattern
pattern recognition and hypothesis testing properties i mean
basically, ART system is an unsupervised learning model, consisting of a comparison field and a recognition field composed of neurons, a vigilance parameter, and a reset module
the vigilance parameter is very important on the system since higher vigilance produces highly detailed memories
while lower vigilance results in more general memories
this means that in the first case we get many fine-grained categories and in the second one fwer more-general categories
and who choses the vigilance parameter? the algorith or the user?
the vigilance parameter is a tuning variable for the algorithm. the user chooses it to suite its needs
ok
back to where i was
The comparison field takes an input vector and transfers it to its best match in the recognition field
but how does it learn actually ?
Its best match is the single neuron whose wieght vector matches the input vector
how are those parameters tuned?
i'll get to that claudiu..patience..
Each recognition field neuron outputs a negative signal to each of the other recognition field neurons and inhibits their output accordingly
the next step after the input vector is classified is for the reset module to compare the strength of the recognition match to the vigilance parameter
If the vigilance threshold is met, training starts
also you said that ART networks are known for their self-organizing pattern recognition and hypothesis testing properties. what do you mean by hypothesis testing properties ? andreiserea: Otherw
Otherwise, if the match level does not meet the vigilance parameter, the input is discarded, the firing recognition neuron is inhibited until a new input vector is applid
i'll get back to your question as soon as i finish the entire presentation
to continue...
training commences only upon completion of a search procedure
In the search procedure, recognition neurons are disabled one by one by the reset function until the vigilance parameter is satisfied by a recognition match
i supose ART uses a lot of resources
if no committed recognition neuron’s match meets the vigilance threshold, then an uncommitted neuron is committed and adjusted towards matching the input vector
that depends on the quantity of data to be learnt
this way, the network learns about new inputs.
now..about your first question claudiu...about training the ART neural network
There are two basic methods of training ART-based neural networks: slow and fast

In the slow learning method, the degree of training of the recognition neuron’s weights towards the input vector is calculated to continuous values with differential equations and is thus dependent on the length of time the input vector is presented
now, on fast learning, things are different
the equations used are algebraic

i will present Naive Bayes
Naive Bayes is another technique that is used in data classification.
It derives from Bayes's theorem but involves specific independence conditions.
Bayes's theorem proposes a formula that relates the probability of event A given the marginal probability of event B.
It is a simple but powerful formula in itself, however it is rather complicated to implement in it's original form.
Naive Bayes simplifies the formula by adding the assumption that events are independent of each-other.
That means much simpler and faster calculations as the whole formula reduces to computing a multiplication of independent smaller fractions.
why is it hard to implement if it is quite simple?
ok i will answer, but first let me finish presenting it
just a couple more words
please stefan - questions afterwards !
Overall Naive Bayes may make oversimplified assumptions but it does produce quite unexpectedly good results.
There are a few variations over the implementations, but the most wide spread are the Bernoulli form and the multinomial form.
leaves the room
As a quick overview, given an N dimensional space ( like a N words in a text ), a vector in the Bernoulli form will be composed of ones and zeroes if the keywords appear or not in the text.
The multinomial form actually counts the number of appearances, so it will give a more realistic estimation.
joins the room
Between the two, the multinomial form is only marginally slower but almost always gives better results that the Bernoulli form.
